body:
# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465?src=pr&el=h1) Report
> Merging [#5465](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465?src=pr&el=desc) into [master](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/commit/d5a5b9d9f1f1efb67ffed4d8e6ef3e0a06467bed?src=pr&el=desc) will **decrease** coverage by `<.01%`.
> The diff coverage is `n/a`.

[![Impacted file tree graph](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465/graphs/tree.svg?width=650&token=WdLKlKHOAU&height=150&src=pr)](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465?src=pr&el=tree)

```diff
@@            Coverage Diff             @@
##           master    #5465      +/-   ##
==========================================
- Coverage   79.13%   79.13%   -0.01%     
==========================================
  Files         488      488              
  Lines       30608    30608              
==========================================
- Hits        24223    24222       -1     
- Misses       6385     6386       +1
```


| [Impacted Files](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465?src=pr&el=tree) | Coverage Δ | |
|---|---|---|
| [airflow/models/taskinstance.py](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465/diff?src=pr&el=tree#diff-YWlyZmxvdy9tb2RlbHMvdGFza2luc3RhbmNlLnB5) | `93.02% <0%> (-0.17%)` | :arrow_down: |

------

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [d5a5b9d...2909551](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5465?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

> I thought Python type hints and types in docstrings were 2 different things? If the docs include types from type hinting, I'd be happy to remove it from the docs.

I think we will need to add this extension to get typehints automatically taken in to accounts in doc generation: https://pypi.org/project/sphinx-autodoc-typehints/ . But I think it's worth it :)

I like where it goes, and I am all for merging it . I have some other changes coming in AIP-7 proposal https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/4932/files#diff-6a3371457528722a734f3c51d9238c13R33 - but I will be happy to merge my changes with those ones. 

One proposal though - since this is quite a big change to CONTRIBUTING.md maybe we should also consider switching to .rst from .md ? I used an automated conversion tool in the past (I think any tool works here) and Github supports .rst rendering as well as .md

How should we proceed with this?  @galuszkak are you still able to work on this?  If not, I can rebase it, add my fix, and create a yet-another PR for this issue.  

I explored adding more tests to clarify / document status quo ante, specifically addressing the DST transition [here](https://github.com/dstandish/airflow/commit/81f67ad41d968c259acab5427262b20aeaa4c30d#diff-4be935cc287b881b26e13e2fcc9c6cae), but it's a bit of a rabbit hole to try and document status quo behavior for all possible edge cases and I'm not sure it's actually beneficial to do so.

@potiuk you have relevant experience here, perhaps you can offer some guidance?

My main interest is standardizing everything to pendulum so that we can reduce some of the ambiguity and inconsistencies, but I think that it makes sense to close out this PR first.
@dstandish I plan to work on this today evening. Will update later on it.

Here is the first draft of the alternative approach to move zombie detection down to `DagBag`: https://github.com/seelmann/incubator-airflow/commit/6ce4f56b907efdf34db780c26b986bab4225d045

Missing: more tests, verify SQL query is fast (uses index), find out if throttling makes sense, ...
@ashb - Changes implemented as per your comments

> I think we will need to add this extension to get typehints automatically taken in to accounts in doc generation: https://pypi.org/project/sphinx-autodoc-typehints/ . But I think it's worth it :)

That would be a nice addition!

> I'm not sure what the added benefit would be of that. I'd say either make all Markdown files (readme, contributing, todo & updating) in the root of the project .rst format or leave them as-is. 


The benefit would be just consistency - we have plenty of docs in .rst format already :). These are all different level of doc - the documentation of the product rather than "Contributor's" documentation. I just thought that if we make it .rst we could also make it part of the "readthedocs" docs generated. However it's not strictly necessary as these are two different types of docs. So I am OK with leaving the top level docs in .md format as well. Maybe others can have stronger opinions here (@mik-laj  - I think you had some thoughts there ).
Yeah. I think it was a one-time error, there is no need to prevent it in the future @mik-laj -> I'd merge it today before 1.10.4 beta goes out (but we have to wait for master docs fix).
@ultrabug I'll come back to this after the 1.10.4 release is done (which we're starting on today.)
Merging, passed check_docs

+1!

> The diff coverage is `100%`.

[![Impacted file tree graph](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5455/graphs/tree.svg?width=650&token=WdLKlKHOAU&height=150&src=pr)](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5455?src=pr&el=tree)


|---|---|---|
| [airflow/configuration.py](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5455/diff?src=pr&el=tree#diff-YWlyZmxvdy9jb25maWd1cmF0aW9uLnB5) | `91.94% <100%> (ø)` | :arrow_up: |
| [.../contrib/operators/jenkins\_job\_trigger\_operator.py](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5455/diff?src=pr&el=tree#diff-YWlyZmxvdy9jb250cmliL29wZXJhdG9ycy9qZW5raW5zX2pvYl90cmlnZ2VyX29wZXJhdG9yLnB5) | `72.5% <0%> (+5.5%)` | :arrow_up: |

------

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5455?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5455?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [06dba66...253fdc3](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5455?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
@ashb will this PR be in 1.10.4?

I think that it is worth moving the entire file to the docs directory and at the same time change its format to rst.
This is important for several reasons.
* creates space for another document that was discussed on the dev list
https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/af7637c61acbb877dc68f337b633b2c34a43f91a2ebafc61208daf0c@%3Cdev.airflow.apache.org%3E
* creates one source of knowledge. The user has all the materials available in one place.
* historical versions of documents become available in the compiled version - https://readthedocs.org/projects/airflow/
* unifies the documentation format in repo. 
* easier editing of the file For example: you will be able to copy the fragment from one place to another.
* linking between documents was difficult. It is now possible to refer to this document from the documentation. See: http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/directives.html#directive-versionchanged This is more important when we also change the changelog file

It is difficult for me to find serious disadvantages of this change. I see a lot of advantages.

In my opinion, this PR is not correct.
We have two static methods:
* _check_zone_operation_status method accepts 5 arguments
* _check_global_operation_status  method accepts 4 arguments

This change applies to the second case - `_check_global_operation_status`, but 5 arguments are passed.

My fixup commit is available:
```
curl https://termbin.com/0mun | git am
```

I think that we should not mock the private methods of the class we are testing.  This causes us to have the wrong impression that something is tested when it really is not. 
Here is an example of how I would like these tests to look:
https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/master/tests/contrib/hooks/test_gcp_cloud_build_hook.py

Thanks @kurtqq & @ashb 
Need me to rebase from upstream/master & squash again, or do you squash when merging?
@dstandish Good point, will add it into PR, Thanks
Nope, tests are green and we can handle the squashing from the github UI.

I agree with @mik-laj there seem to be a confusion between the two functions. i assume the None argument is because the author mixed up the zone argument of the 2nd function.

The intresting question is how the test passed if the call sends more parameters than the signature of the function. Weird.
@OmerJog this fragment is not tested, because private method is mocked.

Indeed I see now that there is a confusion between global and zone. And the problem is missing test for _wait_for_operation_to_complete. It would be great to extend the test suite to add tests covering this method in different circumstances (in test_gcp_compute_hook.py).
@kurtqq - would that be something you are willing/have time to do ?

@chronitis Can you see if I've made some silly mistake on cherry-picking this back to the release branch -- it's failing on it's Python 2 tests. https://github.com/apache/airflow/commit/3fc191c1416ac85021539153fe9ed1449c15f393

Come the morning I'll pull this out of the branch to get a 1.10.4beta1 out but hopefully we can get it back in before we create the first release candidate.
Oh got it - str (py3) vs basesxtring (py2)
PTAL @ashb @feng-tao @kaxil

Observe error

```
51) ERROR: Failure: SyntaxError (invalid syntax (branch_operator.py, line 51))
----------------------------------------------------------------------
   Traceback (most recent call last):
    .tox/py27-backend_mysql-env_docker/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/loader.py line 418 in loadTestsFromName
      addr.filename, addr.module)
    .tox/py27-backend_mysql-env_docker/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/importer.py line 47 in importFromPath
      return self.importFromDir(dir_path, fqname)
    .tox/py27-backend_mysql-env_docker/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/importer.py line 94 in importFromDir
      mod = load_module(part_fqname, fh, filename, desc)
    tests/operators/test_branch_operator.py line 25 in <module>
      from airflow.operators.branch_operator import BaseBranchOperator
   SyntaxError: invalid syntax (branch_operator.py, line 51)
```

Only Py2 tests failed, and caused by this line: https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/v1-10-test/airflow/operators/branch_operator.py#L51

```python
def execute(self, context: Dict):
```
Thanks @XD-DENG - that error was from a previous cherry-pick on to v1-10-test that I've just fixed.

# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5476?src=pr&el=h1) Report

Hey @Fokko @ashb @gerardo @ashb @BasPH  - I finally fixed all the issues and have a CI-green version (I believe) of the last "docker image" PR. I got the old Kubernetes scripts working (slightly improved them) and I think it is pretty much ready for final review. It works for my account build: https://travis-ci.org/potiuk/airflow/builds/550362466 but the build for apache are super-slow so I wait for the result on apache.

I will work with @gerardo as a follow-up on docker-compose-enabled version of Kubernetes tests next so the improvements will continue, but for now I think it's past the time we start using benefits  of the built-in image.

The last version has a few fixes to the kubernetes build approach:
* I adapted the scripts to root user inside the CI image
* I use --no-deps switch in kubernetes compose so that there are no two copies of postgres/mysql and other images while the tests are running
* I figured out a way how we can make sure latest versions of dependencies (within requirements from setup.py) are always installed for the tests
* pylint/mypy/docs/flake are all using the docker images - so it is super-easy to reproduce the CI static code checks 
@BasPH  - I also updated docs as part of my change. I am happy to merge it with your changes, or you can merge yours into mine - as you wish.

Please review! I look forward to merging it finally!
LGTM

Some more context around why we need this two metrics:
With `pool.starving_tasks.<pool_name>` we are measuring the number of tasks that are not able to get a pool slot when the pool is full. It gives us an idea about how many more slots we should add to the pool to accommodate all the tasks if the pool is over utilized. However, when the pool size is too large while there are very few tasks, `pool.starving_tasks.<pool_name>` won't give us much insight about how "under-utilized" a pool is and here is where `pool.open_slots.<pool_name>` and `pool.used_slots.<pool_name>` come in to play. 

The reason we need both `pool.open_slots.<pool_name>` and `pool.used_slots.<pool_name>` is that it is easier to tell the utilization rate if we have both metrics on the same graph without the need to go to the Airflow UI to check the pool size.

We have very similar metrics on the executor side (https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/master/airflow/executors/base_executor.py#L125-L127).

![Screen Shot 2019-06-25 at 4 11 44 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6065051/60139856-5c258f80-9764-11e9-899a-35b720d4d4fe.png)

We will have a chart for each pool similar to above

The way this is done feels like it would cause problems if there is a space in the environment var it expands.

A workaround would be to set the command as 

```
sql_alchemy_conn_cmd = bash -c 'echo ${POSTGRES_HOST}:${POSTGRES_PASSWORD}@postgres.com'
```
Thanks, but don't worry about back-porting. We (the committers) will do that as we prefer to record the commit it is cherry-picked from. I'll deal with getting this in to the release.
Could you please give this PR and your commits a more descriptive title.

@BasPH 

> @potiuk
> 
> > One proposal though - since this is quite a big change to CONTRIBUTING.md maybe we should also consider switching to .rst from .md ? I used an automated conversion tool in the past (I think any tool works here) and Github supports .rst rendering as well as .md
> 
> I'm not sure what the added benefit would be of that. I'd say either make all Markdown files (readme, contributing, todo & updating) in the root of the project .rst format or leave them as-is. One problem I encountered before was pictures in .rst files and the Github rendering didn't work nicely together. In my vague memory I used a raw tag together with a float to align the picture on the right and Github wouldn't render it correctly. Since the readme only shows images inline, I don't know if it would be a problem if we'd rewrite it to .rst files, something we would have to test.

One benefit is that .rst files can be easily included in the generated documentation on https://airflow.apache.org/.
(Yes I merged this without waiting for travis. I tested this locally.)
@ashb @ffinfo any other changes?
@OmerJog there are no changes in "code" for the functionality of the airflow product, nor its tests. The changes are in a markdown format for the readme
@mrshu  lgtm thanks to implementing this

The check that has failed is [`Check license header`](https://travis-ci.org/apache/airflow/jobs/550739577) and the error doesn't seem to be related to this PR: `Our attempt to download rat locally to /tmp/lib/apache-rat-0.12.jar failed.`.

I see the [same error](https://travis-ci.org/apache/airflow/jobs/550526211) with [another recent PR](https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/5481) so I am guessing there's some problem with the Travis build? Is there any such known issue?

I'm also noticing that the `create_namespaced_pod` function of the kubernetes client (that we use in `run_pod` in the `PodLauncher` which calls the `KubernetesRequestFactory`) accepts a `V1Pod` object as an argument, which would mean we can skip this whole process of serialization from `object -> dict -> json/yaml`. Thoughts on this? I feel like there are significant amounts of code we can simplify.

Would you still suggest me to port this code as per `master`? How would these changes get integrated into `1.10.3` in that case because that is what we are currently using in my company (and have other scripts which break if run against master)?

You should be able to do this outside of the Airflow code base through Python imports.  This article explains the method importing custom operators https://www.astronomer.io/guides/airflow-importing-custom-hooks-operators/

Unless you want to mess with the Flask UI going with the method proscribed in this article should work fine.

In conf we want to deprecate "historical convenience functions" get, getint, getboolean, etc. However the current code doesn't issue a deprecation warning if any of these function is called.
